description:
Well the Lego Movie of course was a hit with critics and fans alike. It's now grossed almost half a billion dollars. The title song, though, wasn't quite awesome enough to win an Oscar on Sunday. That honour went to Glory from the US civil rights film Selma. Quite a few other things though seem to be going okay for Lego right now. The Danish toy maker's just revealed net profits for last year up 15% to $1 billion. Not much more than a decade ago Lego was on the brink of bankruptcy. I asked chief financial officer John Goodwin how the turnaround had happened.

We really focus back on our central brick-building experience and making sure that that was exciting and relevant to the children and that really has been the foundation of that string of ten years' worth of results. Such that we're now four times the size in terms of revenue than what we were back in 2004.

I was wondering, though, how far Lego's moved away from what it used to be when I was a child, a manufacturer of bricks that you clicked together. Is it less of a physical toy now?

Oh, no, absolutely not. I think the physical building experience is still absolutely central to everything that we do. And what we've done over the period of time has complemented that core building and creative opportunity with additional elements that allow our children to get more immersed in the overall creative experience.
